prior_works.title: Identification and Inference in Nonlinear Difference-in-Differences Models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the changes-in-changes (CiC) approach that identifies entire counterfactual outcome distributions via monotone rank mappings over time; the Triple Changes estimator directly extends these CiC identification ideas from a two-way DID setting to a three-way (DDD) design.

prior_works.title: The Incidence of Mandated Maternity Benefits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formalizes DDD as a credible alternative to simple DID by differencing out confounders using an unaffected comparison margin; the new paper generalizes this DDD logic from mean effects to distributional effects via CiC.

prior_works.title: Semiparametric Difference-in-Differences Estimators
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Clarifies identification of treatment effects in DID with minimal functional-form assumptions; the Triple Changes estimator leverages this semiparametric tradition when articulating nonparametric, distributional identification conditions for a DDD-CiC setting.

prior_works.title: What Mean Impacts Miss: Distributional Effects of Welfare Reform
prior_works.authors: Marianne Bertrand Bitler; Jonah B. Gelbach; Hilary W. Hoynes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates that mean-based DID can obscure important heterogeneity and advocates distributional methods in policy analysis; this motivates the paper’s shift from average DDD to a CiC-based DDD that recovers full counterfactual distributions.

prior_works.title: Quantile Treatment Effects in Difference in Differences
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides identification and estimation of quantile treatment effects in DID under conditional parallel trends; the Triple Changes estimator complements this by offering a CiC-style distributional identification and then extending it to a triple-difference design.

prior_works.title: Natural and Quasi-Experiments in Economics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Synthesizes quasi-experimental strategies and emphasizes DDD as a way to bolster credibility beyond DID; the paper builds on this design insight and supplies the distributional identification needed to take DDD beyond averages.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution—extending triple differences to the changes-in-changes paradigm—rests on unifying two influential strands. First, Athey and Imbens (2006) established the CiC framework, showing how monotone rank mappings can nonparametrically identify entire counterfactual outcome distributions in a DID setting. This provides the conceptual and technical backbone for moving beyond mean effects under parallel trends toward distributional identification. Second, Gruber (1994) popularized the triple-difference design as a practical way to relax DID’s parallel trends assumption by using an additional, unaffected margin. Meyer (1995) further codified DDD within the design-based causal inference toolkit, motivating its use when conventional DID credibility is strained.
Abadie (2005) advanced semiparametric DID identification, reinforcing the value of minimal functional form assumptions—an ethos mirrored in this paper’s nonparametric distributional identification for DDD. Meanwhile, Bitler, Gelbach, and Hoynes (2006) demonstrated empirically that policy evaluations focused on averages can miss meaningful heterogeneity, providing direct impetus to develop distributional DDD methods that recover full counterfactual distributions. Finally, Callaway and Li (2023) supplied a parallel, quantile-DID route to distributional effects under conditional parallel trends; the present work complements this by adopting CiC-style assumptions and elevating them to a triple-difference design suited for targeted policies. Together, these works directly shape the Triple Changes estimator’s identification strategy and its motivation to deliver distributional policy effects where traditional DID/DDD fall short.
